awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Electric-field Directed Assembly of 3D Chiral Metamaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
Chirality is a fundamental characteristic of living matter. Chiral metamaterials are engineered structures composed of periodic metallodielectric building blocks that exhibit chirality. The resonance of individual building blocks and strong coupling between neighbors allow the realization of exotic electromagnetic properties such as negative refractive index and giant circular dichroism. Chiral metamaterials could revolutionize many modern technologies including superlenses, optical communication, cloaking devices, and high resolution sensors. Three-dimensional chiral metamaterials are, however, extremely difficult to fabricate especially in an economical and large scale fashion. This research will utilize asymmetric particles as building blocks and exploit a time-varying electric field to guide the assembly of these particles into long-range periodic chiral structures. The solution-based process could potentially reduce the fabrication cost significantly. The compatibility of the electrode design with existing microelectronic manufacturing infrastructures will also open the door to commercialize innovative metamaterials for emerging applications. The research team will also engage both high school and undergraduate students with immersive research experiences. Learning modules such as "Colloids, surfactants, and our daily lives" and "Optical technology that changes our lives" will be developed in collaboration with K-12 teachers. The research findings will also be included in the development of several multi-disciplinary courses such as "Engineering of Soft Materials" and "Nanotechnology: From Molecules to Machines". 

The goal of this collaborative project is to use electric fields to assemble Janus metallodielectric particles into a periodic array of chiral clusters as an efficient bottom-up route for making three-dimensional chiral metamaterials. Particles with increasing morphological complexity will be fabricated as building blocks by glancing angle deposition. A liquid electrode cell will be built for the manipulation of the Janus particles via time-varying electric fields in three-dimensions. The Coulomb, dipolar, and electrohydrodynamic interactions will be exploited to guide the assembly of Janus particles into chiral clusters. Further manipulation of the chirality of the electric fields will transform the racemic mixture into enantiomerically pure clusters. The photonic response of the fabricated structures and their applications will be measured and explored in both near-infrared and visible regions. Numerical simulations will also be performed to elucidate the particle assembly mechanisms, their optical properties, and guide experimental optimization. The collaborative and iterative nature of this project will reveal the interrelationship between the design of fundamental building blocks, control of lattice symmetry, and targeted photonic properties of chiral metamaterials.

por.por_cntn:
The ultimate goals of this proposal are three-folds: firstly to design and produce various Janus micro-/nanoparticles using shadowing sphere lithography method; second, to perform in-situ self-assembly and optical characterization of the Janus particles under electric field and understanding the structure-property relationship; and third to explore the sensor and other applications of the self-assembled structures. During the project period, we have met most of these goals and made significant achievements in the following areas: (1) To design complex plasmonic nanohole arrays. We have designed elliptical nanohole arrays, compound nanohole arrays, chiral nanohole arrays, rods on nanohole arrays, etc. (Fig. 1), demonstrated that the enhanced optical transmission (EOT) peak could be tuned by the structure, complex lattice design, as well as symmetry breaking; strong Fano resonance can be produced; and new EOT mode can be introduced. These properties can be predicted or understood via numerical calculations. (2) To realize composite plasmonic metamaterials. By combining dual-source deposition and nanosphere lithography (Fig. 2), we have fabricated composite plasmonic structures with arbitrary compositions and various shapes. We have discovered that the plasmonic resonant properties of these structures can be systematically tuned by the composition. By co-deposition of Ag and magnetic metals, we have fabricated various magneto-plasmonic metamaterials. The polarization response of these structures can be dynamically tuned by external magnetic fields. (3) To achieve gradient plasmonic nanostructure fabrication. By introducing varied curved substrates, we have demonstrated that various plasmonic nanostructures with continuous size tuning can be simultaneously fabricated (Fig. 3). These structures show gradient plasmonic properties and can be used for high throughput screening of plasmonic structures for different applications. (4) To improve the performance of plasmonic sensors. First, we have shown that using metal-dielectric composite nanostructures, one can significantly improve the sensitivity of localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) sensors. Second, by introducing a polarized difference spectrum, one can also greatly improve the figure of merit of the plasmonic sensors. Last, with the chiral nanohole structures, we have demonstrated high sensitivity of chiral molecule detection.  These results and fabrication strategies will have a profound impact on plasmonics and nanofabrication, as well as in the structural and composition design of future active metamaterials and their applications.

 

This project has resulted in a total of 15 peer reviewed journal publications, 3 conference talks, and 3 PhD theses. We have also trained a total of 6 graduate students, 1 undergraduate student, and 1 postdoctoral associate. Four students have successfully received their PhD degrees. Two PhD students found jobs in industry while one just got a job in Department of Energy associated national lab.
